sp.p: You had beſt turn Informer; 'tis the beſt employment I know of for you: His Majeſty is well help'd up with ſuch Juſtices of the Peace as you are: There's too many ſuch, God help us, makes us at that paſs we are at; they will Acquit a Man for Houſe-breaking, and Commit a Man to Goal for taking a lawful Courſe for what's his own.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Well, if you were not my Boſom-Friend, this ſhould not paſs unpuniſhed; but we forget our Dinner, that will be ſpoiled while we ſtand trifling our time away.

div.stage: Ex. S. Peter, L. Lovejoy & Modiſh.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: How think you now of my way of Curing the Head-Ach?

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: I like well enough of it; 'tis ſoon done, and not very Chargeable, a Shilling's the moſt it Coſts: Who would not give that for ſuch a Refreſhment?

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: 'Tis as certain a Cure for the Head-Ach, as your Jeſuits Powder for an Ague: I have try'd all Experiments, and find nothing like it.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: It hath one ill property that I know of, it ſets a Man in for all day, if he like his Company.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Who would not bear with a ſmall Inconveniency to get rid of a dolorous Pain? the Head-ach is as bad or worſe than Teethach, and that they ſay will make a Dog run mad.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Your Phiſick makes a Man wanton; e'en like Opium, it ſets a Man a doſing that he never feels his Pain and knows not whether he be ſick or well.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Other Phiſick makes a Man ſick before it works, and that I think no body likes; beſides, 'tis expected you ſhould keep your Chamber with it; this requires no ſuch Obſervances, but you are at your Liberty, free and unconfin'd; it adds a Beauty to the Face, and makes a Man look as freſh as a Roſe in June.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: It makes a Man bold I know, and do that which is moſt againſt the Byaſs of his Will and Inclination at another time: Thus Alexander kill'd his Friend in his Wine; an Act which could he have recalled again, he would have given his new vanquiſht World, and thought it well beſtowed.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: I have or'e ſtayd my time; come, will you walk, and as we go we'll end this hot Debate. Exit Friendly and Sparkiſh

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: I knew ſhe would try your Patience before you got loſe from her; for all her Pretenſions I would not be a handſome young Gentleman in her way when ſhe is in the Humour, for more than I will ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: She is as unreaſonable as a loſing Gamſter; there's no parting with her without a Quarrel; whatſoever Mans Occaſions be, ſhe will be firſt ſerved under penalty of loſing her Favour for the future. Mrs. Lettice, is there no ſeeing Madam Julia?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: At Eight a Clock this Evening if you come I'le ſo contrive it you ſhall be in private with her, till then farewel. Ex. Lettice.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: This Woman, my Lady as you call her, hath put me in a Heat with her Clack; ſhe will have ſix Words to your one, make the beſt uſe of your time you can; 'tis an Aegyptian Slavery to keep her Company.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Modiſh your Servant; I have been enquiring for you in all your Haunts, and could not hear of you to acquaint you with my good fortune. I have received a Challeng from a perſon of Honour to meet her this Evening, Eight the time, a clear Stage, and no Quarter to be given on either ſide, and without Seconds Boy.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: At this rate you may, for all I know, be glad to turn Child again, and cry kings-truce for a breathing while; you take like Tinder and are tranſported with the Thoughts of your hot Ingagement like a raw Soldier, nothing but Fire and Fagot will content you; but after an Engagement or two, he fights with Moderation, keeps Rank and File and comes up with his Leader.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: I queſtion not to come off with flying Colours: How malicious thou art, becauſe thy croſs Fate will not afford thee one happy Day in a year, thou wouldſt have every body elſe under the like Circumſtances: I hate ſuch ill-humour'd ſnarling Companions; and ſo I leave you to fret in your Greaſe, 'till you return to a better Humour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: I'le lay my life this Appointment is one of Lettice's contriving, to keep her Lady imploy'd while we are together in the Evening; how fond the Fool is of it!

q.l: Both Plants and Trees their certain Seaſon know,
Riſe with the Sun and wither when 'tis low;
Beaſts their appointed time to ſeek their Prey,
They range all Night, and to their Dens at Day:
Yet Man the Lord of all, that's here below
Courts Care and Toyl, and will no time beſtow
To eaſe his reſtleſs and diſturbed Mind;
Courts what is bad, and leaves what's good behind.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth ACT.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter S. Peter Lovejoy, Friendly and Modiſh.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: AS poſitive as you are S. Peter, I am not bound to pin my Faith upon any mans Sleeve in the World, neither will I be perſwaded to act againſt my Reaſon, except you can bring better Arguments for what you have affirm'd, than I can againſt it; I won't be bubled out of that little Senſe I have left me.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: What Argument would you have me undertake to gratifie your Curioſity? I'le uſe my weak Endeavours to give you ſatisfaction, if that will do.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Pray then make good, if you can, your Maxim, that you are always forcing upon People to make them believe there's no Whore after Marriage.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: If he makes that Argument good, it will go a great way in reconciling the World, and he will perform a friendly Office to the Publick.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: To the Point in hand then. Firſt I would know if you take our Lawmakers to be wiſe and conſiderate men or no.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: No doubt they were ſo; who denies that is to blame.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: Beyond all contradiction, there's no denying it.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: That granted you go a great way in confirming my Argument; for I find by my reading, that there can be no Baſtard born in Wedlock, therefore no Whore after Marriage. What have ye to ſay againſt it Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: As I live the Knight ſpeaks reaſon, deny it who can; I am convinc't.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: On my word I cannot contradict what he ſaith, nor will I go about it.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Nay 'tis but a Folly, having granted the Premiſes, to go about to deny the Concluſion. Let Reaſon rule you; and tho it be a vulgar Error which I have here confuted, ſit down ſatisfied there are thouſands miſtaken beſides your ſelf, which I hope in a ſhort time to convince and make ſenſible of their Errour.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: But in this caſe where the Husband is beyond the Seas your Argument will not hold good, the Law is expreſly againſt you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Right, but there our Lawmakers were ſhort-ſighted; for is it reaſonable becauſe the Husband is beyond the Seas the Wife ſhould loſe her teeming? Beſides ſhe doth it out of meer neceſſity, and againſt that you know there is no Law.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: As I live well anſwered; he hath both Senſe and Reaſon on his ſide, and againſt that there is no diſputing.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: This is nothing but what is common that I have made out to you; but I hear the Virtuoſo's are about a Project, which if it take effect, will be worthy their Pains and Labour, and very beneficial to the World.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: What may it be S. Peter, if a man may inquire without offence, this uſe you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: I find you are out at Myſtery; ſure you converſe with none but thick-ſcul'd Fellows you hear not of it; why they have undertaken, nay upon the matter brought it to perfection too, to make a Man a Woman.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: An excellent Project this. But how is it ſo beneficial to the World as you talk of?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: There you are ſhort again of your Comprehenſion: How many great Eſtates have been loſt for want of an Heir?

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: This doth not at all mend the matter, the making a Man a Woman; it had been ſomething to have made a Woman a Man, that might have been of uſe where an Heir Male had been wanting.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: That's implied, if they compaſs the one the other comes of Courſe; for 'tis leſs trouble to make a Woman a Man, than 'tis to make a Man a Woman.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: I acquieſce Sir, and modeſtly ſubmit to better Judgments.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: But if this Argument prevails among us, where are all the Cuckolds and Witals the World hath ſo much talkt of? There are no ſuch Creatures; 'tis ſtrange we ſhould be thus impoſed upon, and ſwallow it for a Truth for divers Ages.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p:
Why they are agreed, and gone a different Voyage,
the Witals to ſeek the Phoenix in Arabia, and the Cuckolds the Unicorn in the Iſle of Pines.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Say you ſo Sir, then without doubt at their Return, they will make a ſaving Voyage of it; for a Phoenix and an Unicorn will be worth the ſeeing, being ſuch Rarities as were never yet ſeen, tho much talk'd of; they muſt of neceſſity gain abundance of Wealth by them.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: No doubt of it, when theſe things come to paſs they need not want Mony; for I look upon a Wital or a Cuckold, to be as ſtrange, or a ſtranger ſight than the Unicorn or Phoenix, and may as ſoon be found: But I have Affairs in hand which muſt not be neglected, and therefore muſt beg your Pardon for leaving you thus abruptly. Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: On my word, the Knight argues Reaſon, and by his Reading finds we are impoſed upon, and frankly undeceives the ignorant, and deſerves Commendations for his Care. I find we ſtill may learn, tho we live never ſo long. Exit.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: This Fool takes all the other ſays for Oracles. How ſome are impoſed upon, and yield to things incredible and non-ſenſe; and are prevail'd upon to own Abſurdities and Contradictions, both to Senſe and Reaſon? By which we may ſee, there are Bigots in Opinions as well as in Religion; while ſober Men abandon all ſuch. Follies, and laugh at thoſe that are deluded by them.

q.l: The Ignorant are thus abus'd and gall'd
By thoſe, whoſe buſineſs is to Cheat the World.

div.stage: Enter Julia, and after her Lettice ſinging.

lg.l: Lettice. Since we poor ſlaviſh Women know,
Our men we cannot pick and chuſe,
To him we love we ſay him no,
And both our time and labour loſe.
By our put-off's and fond delays
A lovers Appetite we pall,
And if too long the Gallant ſtays,
His Stomach's gone for good and all.
Or our impatient Amorous Gueſt,
Ʋnknown to us away may ſteal,
And rather than ſtay for a Feaſt,
Take up with ſome courſe homely Meal:
When Opportunity is kind,
Let prudent Women be ſo too;
And if the Man be to her mind,
Be ſure ſhe do not let him go.
The Match ſoon made is happieſt ſtill,
For Love has only there to do;
Let no one marry 'gainſt her Will,
But ſtand off when her Parents woo:
And to the Suiter be not Coy,
For ſhe whom Joynture can obtain,
To let a Fop her Bed enjoy,
Is but a lawful Wench for Gain.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Well thou art as mad a Laſs as ever I met withall; fall Back, fall Edg thou art always merry.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Hang Sorrow, Care will kill a Catt, there's nothing gain'd by thinking, I ſay; it only brings People into Diſtempers: From a melancholy thinking Life I ſtill pray to be delivered.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: And may'ſt thou have thy Wiſh I ſay: But how have you order'd Matters for our Meeting to night in private, as you promiſed?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Well enough I'le warrant you: I have provided my Lady a Companion, which if ſhe parts with preſently, I have loſt my Aim and ſhe her old Wont; when they are together we are ſecure for a ſhort Space of time; I Song you the old Song to put you in mind of what you are going about, that you forget not to make uſe of your Time, for that's a precious Commodity as the World goes.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: I deſerve, if I loſe ſuch an Opportunity as this, to be balk't ever after, and not ſo much as pitied by thee or any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Come will you move toward your Chamber to recieve him when he comes? I'le take that care of you to bring you together, and leave you to agree the matter between your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Your Servant Lady, is my Lady Lovejoy within?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Yes Sir, that Door will bring you to the Room where ſhe is waiting your Coming. Exit Sparkiſh.
So, there's one Couple provided for according to their wiſh; my next care is for the young Couple to ſee them fitted to their Minds.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: My Guide, my Convoy, now I ſee thee I am ſafe; I commit my ſelf wholly to thy Care and Management.

sp.speaker: Lett.
sp.p: I ſhould fit him finely now, if I ſhould ſend him to yonder Couple in the Parlour; but that would ſo diſcourage him he would not look a Woman in the Face this Month, and by that time my Charge above ſtairs would pine her ſelf to death. If you pleaſe to take the pains to walk up ſtairs, the firſt Room on the Right-Hand you will find the Lady you look for; pray be brief, and let's have none of your Canterbury Stories; make uſe of your Time.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: As near as I can I will obſerve your Directions; but ſtill I am of that Philoſophers mind, who blam'd Nature, and not without a Cauſe, who had given Man ſo long a Leſſon and ſo ſhort a time to learn it in. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: How eagerly he purſues that which now he counts his Happineſs! Like Children who are for the preſent fond of Trifles, but ſtraight grow weary of them, and the next pleaſing Object makes them quite forgotten; ſo ſome years hence diſcourſe this eager Lover, he will tell you then that Marriage is a burden too hard for him to bear, and I who am now reſpected and rewarded for my Service, may then lie under the bittereſt Curſes that Malice can invent.

q.l: Before Injoyment Women Angels ſeem▪
But afterwards they are of no Eſteem:
Among our Gallants Miſtreſſes are ſo Common,
They hate the name of Wife or Civil Woman. Ex.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: Thou art always upon Extreams, ſometimes nothing but a Woman can pleaſe thee, at another time, the very ſight of a Woman puts thee into a diſorder: Is there no meen between Loving and Loathing? But good Counſel is thrown away upon ſuch obdurate men as thou art. Exit.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: Now I have the liberty to ſteer my Courſe which way I like beſt, it muſt be after the Female Sex ſtill, tho I have ſuffered ſo deeply by them: I may talk of Religion, but that ſerves only to blind the World. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: I have been in all the likelieſt places hereabouts, to find this Maſter of mine, but can hear no News of him; he's got into ſome blind Corner or other with a Female Sinner: It is a ſtrange thing nothing will Cure him of this Itch of Letchery; for he hath been uſed badly enough by that ſort of Creatures, and to my knowledg is under Cure for his third Clap: But I muſt not give over hunting till I find him, and ſee him ſafe in his Lodging. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sparkiſh, leading in Lady Lovejoy.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Madam, the Obligations you have now laid on me, binds me for ever your devoted Servant; when ſhall I be thus bleſt again? Dear Madam, ſuch Raviſhing Delights as paſs belief, dwell ever in your Eyes, and in your Face a Thouſand Charms are moving; the leaſt of which hath force enough to revive Nature ſetled on the Lees, and turn old Age to Youth.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p:
Sir, You are maker of your own good Fortune; if you ſtyle this your Happineſs, 'tis in your power to give a da • e to
Love, and make it ſhort or laſting, as you pleaſe; I am but like a Dial in Tempeſtuous Weather, of no uſe till you the Sun appear.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: If I may have my wiſh, we will loſe no time, but Huſband it ſtill to promote our Happineſs, that after Ages envying our Felicity, ſhall take their Meaſures from us, and Copy what we leave fairly Written.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtill the fate of Lovers to be at firſt extreamly fond and Court-like, till time that alters all things, makes us Common and Cheap to one another; if not, Age won't be hid; and then what ſeem'd ſo fair and lovely to us, is defaced and blotted▪ like Garments out of Faſhion, not regarded; ſo Love, as Age grows on, declines, and nauſeates what before it moſt longed after.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: With ſickly Appetites all nouriſhment is loathſome, but you have Charms that ſtill create more liking, and add a Luſtre to your heavenly Form, which Captivates at ſight.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Madam, I hear my Maſter in the Street, he is coming home; I thought it part of my Duty to give your Ladyſhip notice.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis well done, go to Bed, I'le let your Maſter in▪ Your abſence will now be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Madam, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: That Door will lead you the Back-way out; your Servant Sir, good Night. Ex. Sparkiſh.
By this means I may make a Diſcovery, and ſee what humour my Knight is in when he is Top and Top-Gallant; for being faulty my ſelf, makes me have a mighty ſuſpicion of other People.

div.stage: Knocking without, L. Lovejoy blows out the Candle, then opens the door.

sp.speaker: Sir. Peter.
sp.p: Well Lettice, Is thy Mrs. ſafe?

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Whiſt, Whiſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Nay, I can be as ſilent as any body if that will do; march on tho it be dark, I ſhall make ſome ſhift or other to follow my Leader.

div.stage: Enter Modiſh leading in Julia, Lettice following them.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: Tranſporting Joys are always ſhort and fleeting, not permanent and durable; the ſatisfaction ſcarce balances the loſs of parting with them; your beauteous form hath made ſuch deep Impreſſion in me, that wanting you I want my better part, and can no more reach Happineſs without you, than Fruit in Autumn ripens without Sun-ſhine.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: This is no time for long Diſcourſes Sir, the Night's far ſpent, and I am indiſpoſed, and much diſordered.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Come Sir, Face to the Right, and follow your Leader: I'le conduct you out, 'tis time to part.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: And muſt we part? Farewel till next we meet, thou Beauteous Soul: Eternal Love wait and attend upon thee. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: The thoughts of future happineſs ſtill make us undergo the greateſt Slavery and Servitude without Repining; but ſlighted once, nothing exceeds the malice of a Woman.

q.l: We Love beyond belief, but if men prove
Once falſe, our hatred far exceeds our Love.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: So, with much ado they are ſeparated; had I let them alone this month together, the laſt Tune would have been Loath to depart: The truth of it is, I ſhould be of the ſame mind, were the Caſe my own, as now 'tis theirs.

q.l: Love knows no Bounds, and moves no common Way,
An Age with Lovers ſeems but a ſhort day. Exit.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: When every bodies turn is ſerv'd, it may be I may be remembred, for 'twould be hard to lye alone all my life-time; but afterwards to lead Apes, is a thing I abhor the thoughts of.

div.stage: Enter Lady Lovejoy, and Sir Peter following her.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Urge me no more, you know I am in my Nature reconcilable, and therefore you uſe me as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Thou art as Waſpiſh this Morning, as the Barber that kill'd his Horſe, becauſe he would not ſtand to be trim'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Lovejoy.
sp.p: You are as void of Senſe as the Woman, that becauſe her Gallant turn'd her off, diſcover'd the Intriegue to her Husband, and made a Weſtminster buſineſs of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I think Edmonton Air hath made thee ſharp-witted; you are ſo quick at Repartee, there's no ſpeaking to you.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: There is no Air will alter you from what you are: A dull Drone, that cannot make a Warrant without the Statute-Book, nor a Mittimus without the help of your Clark, forſooth.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Prithee be not ſo angry, we have all our failings; thou know'ſt we muſt bear with ſmall faults.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Here's another that creates me trouble hourly, but I'le quit my hands of her: Lettice, I would have you provide your ſelf of a place, for I find you are not for my turn, therefore pray pack up, and be moving: There's what is due to you.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Short warning, I would gladly know the Cauſe.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: 'Tis enough I will have it ſo.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: She hath been a good Servant to thee; don't turn her away for a ſmall fault.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: You may do what you pleaſe with your Men, pray let me alone with my Maids.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, I can diſpoſe of my ſelf without giving you a further trouble.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Stay, and take that along with you:gives her mony. I earn'd that laſt Night for you; you had had it then, 'twas deſigned for you, but being gone to Bed you miſt of it; and I ſhould be as unjuſt as you, ſhould I defraud you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Sits the Wind in that Door? then 'tis time for me to be moving, for fear of an after-Reckoning; in a little time her heat will be over. Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p:
You ſee by this, and find by dayly experience, that your ſly pretending Coxcomb, who one would think, had neither Life nor Soul in him, will be as ſweet on a Whore in a Corner, as the daring Hector, who makes it his buſineſs to Debauch himſelf and others; yet I am ſtill of the Opinion, your half-witted Men make the beſt Husbands, becauſe they are fitteſt to be impoſed
upon, and may be wrought into what Form we beſt like of.

q.l: We Marry that our Loves may ſetled be,
Yet nothing pleaſes like Variety.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Ladies, You ſee at laſt I am deſerted by my Lady, who have made it my whole employment to ſerve you to the utmoſt of my power, but am now out of a Capacity to ſerve you further.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: There can be nothing laid to thy Charge by us; we muſt own thou haſt been diligent in thy Office: But you muſt finiſh the work you have begun, or we are in a worſe Condition than ever.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: If ſhe leaves us now in this perplexing doubt, 'tis Inhumanity beyond Example.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Ladies I would not have you deſpair, but be aſſiſting in contriving your own good Fortune; there ſhall be nothing wanting in me to forward it, if it be in my power.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Set us but in the way; then, if we follow not thy Directions the fault lies at our Door, not yours.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Do but tell us what we ſhall do to attain what you have ſo ſucceſsfully hitherto carried on, and leave us to perform it.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I muſt ſtill be concern'd in your Affair I'le try my Skill; I think this Plot may take: 'Tis Madam Julia that they all adore, but can but one poſſeſs her; therefore to carry on our Deſign ſhe muſt promiſe them all fair to draw them into the ſnare of Matrimony, upon this condition, that they ſhall be content to be married after the Maſquerading way, in a Diſguiſe; for by that means we may all be provided for to our wiſh; for Mr. Sparkiſh deſires this day to court her for his Wife; the other two you know have long been Suitors: This will be no great Task to undergo; and this performed we gain what we deſire.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: True Lettice, ſtill thy Plots are laid above the reach of Fate to fruſtrate or prevent.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Now I'le leave you and poſſeſs Modiſh with our Stratagem, and leave the reſt to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now Siſter what remains, but that we carry on this Plot with Secrecy ſo happily begun?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: It muſt of force be proſperous; you ſhall have Modiſh: let Sparkiſh be my Prize, and leave the old diſſembling Letcher Serious for Lettice to convert.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.l: Agreed, and all are ſatisfied.
Where differing Humours meet there's always Strife;
But all Contentment in a married Life. Exeunt Ambo.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: As I have uſed your Brothers Houſe, I ſtill obſerved that Sweentneſs in your Carriage and ſuch tranſcendent Beauty in your Face as cannot be reſiſted; what I have ſaid of you, is not▪ ſtrange but common, being the Talk and wiſh of all Beholders.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In Rallery and Jeſt, not Earneſt ſure.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Such Divine Forms as yours, are rather to be worſhip'd and ador'd than made our Mirth and Paſtime.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Now you betray the worſt of Natures, Flattery, and think I take what you ſpeak in Rallery, for real Truth.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: You wrong me much, my Heart and Tongue agree: I heard by chance that Modiſh long had wooed you, which brought me now to know if my ſmall ſervice and the Love I owe you may be accepted with you.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: Would you be ſo unkind to wrong your Friend and prove his Rival in the Choice he hath made?

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Would I not? What is't I would not do to gain your Favour? Make me a promiſe that I ſhall enjoy you, impoſe what 'ere you will I'le undergo it with as much Willingneſs as I would eat or drink to ſtrengthen and ſupport decaying Nature.

sp.speaker: Julia.
sp.p: In that Sir I'le never promiſe any man, but am reſolved who 'ere I marry it ſhall be in a Diſguiſe; and that you may know I have no Averſion for your Perſon I'le make you of my Council: To Morrow I deſign to alter my Condition, if you dare venture to take your Lot or Chance; I am ti'd to make no further Diſcovery, you may. I will provide a Non-con ſhall joyn us, for here will be two more of the ſame Humour to marry in Diſguiſes: Now if you dare to venture, ſo; if not, farewel. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Come what may come I'le venture, for I am acquainted with her Siſter and Lettice too, by which means I may inform my ſelf as to her Garb and Dreſs that I miſtake not this great Concern and hug a Cloud for Juno.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: I was juſt coming to find you out about a matter that concerns me much, my Happineſs depends upon it.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I can ſerve you you know you may command me to my power.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Know then to Morrow is the time appointed: I am to take my Choice unſight unſeen, as the ſaying is: Now if by any means you can inform me which of the three is Julia, for ſo many there is to be provided for, you'll eternally oblige me.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: It happens ſo that I am of the Council, and therefore can inform you; but am obliged to Secrecy, and 'tis not generous to betray my Truſt, nor can I.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Here's Gold for thy Reward; give me ſome private Mark to know her by is all I ask.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: If I may counſel you, take the middle-moſt as they ſtand together; you need no more direction.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: A word's enough to the wiſe: What Luck had I to think of this kind Creature to direct me!Exit.

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Now will he be couſen'd as the Dog who thought he had been going to Breakfaſt, and was going to be hang'd. But 'tis no matter, what ſhe deſign'd for him will be good enough and too good without he were better.

q.l: Who knows, when married, but his roveing Mind
May keep one center and to one prove kind. Exit.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p:
A pretty Frolick this, to be married Incognito, as they call't; but were I concer'd they ſhould look the Bridegroom where they could find him for me; this is like buying a Pig in a Poke, as the old ſaying is. Well I would have you as my Friend to look before
you leap; they will put ſome Trick upon you, you had beſt take heed.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: No, no, I am ſafe enough for that; I have a private Mark to know her by; beſides I have undergon ſo much to gain her Favour as might fill a ſmall Romance; and do you think ſhe will after all deceive me? You wrong her much to ſtart this Queſtion Sir, and me in harbouring ſuch hard Thoughts of her, and were you not my Friend, I ſhould as old as I am, demand ſatisfaction of you for the Affront offer'd.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: I only put the Worſt, the Beſt will help it ſelf; and if for this you are angry you may turn the Buckel of your Girdle behind you, for any thing I care.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: What angry one with another? Let's know the Cauſe: I'le make you Friends again or it ſhall coſt me all the Mony in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: The matter is not worth the ſpeaking of, Mr. Serious can inform you if he pleaſes the Reaſon of our Difference.

sp.speaker: Mr. Serious.
sp.p: I'le as ſoon be hang'd, cant a Man ſpeak a haſty Word but it muſt preſently be brought upon the Stage? I have no Quarrel with any man living that I know of, ſo be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: I am very well ſatisfied there is no difference between you; for my part you are both my Friends and therefore was concern'd.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: 'Twas kindly offer'd. Where do you dine to day, At home or abroad?

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: At Tom's, where Modiſh gives a Veniſon Paſty, where I am ſure your Company will be as acceptable as any that's there.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: I gueſs no leſs and ſhall be glad to wait on you. What ſay you Mr. Serious?

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I think to meet you there, but have ſome Buſineſs of importance muſt be diſpatch'd firſt, then I am for you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Well, we'll expect you Sir. Come Uncle we'll in and drink our Mornings-draught, and then ſet forwards. Ex. omnes.

div.stage: Enter Julia, Flavia and Lettice diſguis'd on one ſide. Modiſh, Sparkiſh and Serious on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: This World's a Lottery; where ſtill the leaſt deſerving are moſt proſperous, and the beſt natur'd, meet the moſt Misfortunes. Beſides, we are impoſed upon, for to one Prize you will find a thouſand Blanks; yet like frank Gameſters ſtill we will be puſhing and urge Ill Fortune to our overthrow, ſtill in purſuit of that which muſt torments us, and part with all our Faculties at once to follow what another ſhall think equal.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: By the World thou art in the right, for in this caſe there can but one poſſeſs the Lovely Julia, the other two muſt take what's left; you are contented I firſt make my Choice.

sp.speaker: Serious, Modiſh.
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Then here I fix, and laugh to ſee you Two deceived and cheated, while I poſſeſs the beauteous Julia, in whoſe Arms I'le ſport my ſelf and dare Ill Fortune to diſturb my Peace.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I ſmile to ſee how confident the Fool is, but I am on ſure ground, and here I make my Choice, and think my ſelf as happy as Conquering Soldiers laden with their Spoils, or Shipwreck't Men juſt landed.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: Then what remains, but that I take this Lady, and fancy her to be the Heavenly Julia? Now to the Prieſt, who ſtays in the Dining-Room, where joyned, we then ſhall know our certain Dooms, who we are tied to lead our Lives withall. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter Lovejoy, Lady Lovejoy and Friendly.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: A Maſquerading ſay you? I thought that had been out of Faſhion.

sp.speaker: Friendly.
sp.p: In ſhort Sir, they are both gone to be married, and Lettice with them; ſhe's to have a Husband too among them.

sp.speaker: L. Lovejoy.
sp.p: Sir Peter, you have manag'd your matter finely, to let them be diſpoſed of unknown to you.

sp.speaker: S. Peter.
sp.p: Tricks of youth, tricks of youth: Girls will have their Frolicks.

div.stage: Enter Serious leading Lettice, Sparkiſh leading Flavia, Modiſh leading in Julia.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: I beg your pardon Sir Peter, for marrying your Siſter without your Conſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What Siſter?

sp.speaker: Lettice.
sp.p: Lettice if you pleaſe, for ſo I think they call me.

sp.speaker: Serious.
sp.p: What, Cheated! Put upon!

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Then I muſt beg your excuſe, for making bold without your leave, with your Beauteous Siſter Madam Julia.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Hey day, how many Julia's ſhall we have? Sure they drop out of the Clouds there is ſo many of them.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Prepare you to ſee a Face, though not ſo Beauteous, yet as true as Julia's. pulls off her Mask

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Tricks as I live! By the World, as Modiſh ſays, I think the World is a Lottery; but we are got among Prizes, I ſee no Blanks.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: Then ſure the faithful Julia is my Wife; for yet ſhe is conceal'd: Come puſh aſide this Cloud, and ſhew thy Beauty.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.p: Then be it as you wiſh, you have your Julia, and I the Man I love above the World.

sp.speaker: Modiſh.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, let diſcontent be baniſhed from all Faces, and only Joy appear: You know the old Proverb is, Marriage and Hanging goes by deſtiny. Come, the Veniſon Paſty is ready by this time: Let's Laugh it out, and make a merry day on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Firſt ſatisfie this good Company how you like your Mornings Work, and then we are for you.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh.
sp.p: Agreed: Come Mr. Serious, you were married firſt, and are the moſt likelieſt to find fault, therefore pray lead the way.

sp.speaker: Serious
sp.l: By me you may perceive as Age grows on,
How we poor Animals are put upon:
Of a bad Chance, 'tis well it proves no worſe,
I doubt not but ſhe will make a careful Nurſe.

sp.speaker: Sparkiſh
sp.l: Tho Chous'd by Madam Julia, yet I find
Great ſatisfaction in my roving Mind:
This Flavia proves as Chaſte as Babes new born,
And ſweet as Roſe-buds in a Summer Morn.

sp.speaker: Modiſh
sp.l: My Joy's too great in words to be expreſt.
In faithful Julia I am double bleſt:
Fortune hath made amends for all her Spite;
Thus after Darkneſs we rejoyce at Light.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter
sp.l: Since all ſeem ſatisfied, why ſhould not we
With Mirth and Joy conclude this Comedy;
Forget what's paſt, and let this happy Night
Conclude all Quarrel, and ſet all things Right.

sp.speaker: Friendly
sp.l: Could we but hope that you were pleas'd, we then
Should reſt ſatisfied, like happy Men;
Who what this World affords, they do poſſeſs;
But your diſlike is our unhappineſs.

div.head: The EPILOGUE.
div.l: CƲSTOM prevails, and you expect we know
To hear an Epilogue before you go.
Our Poet finds your Appetites are nice,
And dares not rule, but gives you this Advice;
Be govern'd by the Learned in the Laws,
Who before Judgment always trie the Cauſe,
And afterward, if for the firſt Offence,
In gentle and kind Terms expreſs their Senſe
In hopes of the Offenders Reformation▪
At leaſt they will allow him Tranſpor ••• ion,
Such is the Goodneſs of our Engliſh Nation.
Then why ſhould you, who here as Judges ſit;
Count all but D • oſs that is not like your Wit?
Wit may be Wit, tho not ſo finely dreſt,
As Senſe without an Oath may be expreſt.
Pray tell me Gallants, is the Face the worſe
Becauſe the Garment's Country like and Courſe?
You are for Beauties, as you are for Wits,
Nothing but what's Extream your Fancy fits.
He that writ beſt never could pleaſe you long,
Sometimes your Humour▪ lies towards a Song;
But that muſt be well worded, and refin'd,
Thus various are the Motions of your Mind,
As Fiſhmongers ſay by their Wares, the Play
And Poet too are freſh and new as they.
Novelties uſe to pleaſe you, but of late
Nothing will do, ſuch is your cruel Fate:
We court your Love, but ſtill we meet our Hate.
If you reſolve ſtill to be ſo ſevere
Thus few will try their Wits to treat you here,
But ſpend what's left, where Men more kind will prove
At leaſt they will return us Love for Love.
They're void of Care and Strife wee'l ſpend our Days
In Love and Friendſhip, and ne're think of Plays.
'Tis the first Fault, and therefore Sirs be kind,
And let the Play a kind Reception find.
